Maniere por fondre la gomme de sois, o ater=
=ment die la gomme dragant ;~
Lons prend por un patar de la dit gomme; il
la fat mettre tremper, dans une demie peinte
dea de plis, pltot pls, qe moin, il fat le
leser comme sa dex jor, pis il fat prendre
une clier et le bien toillier, et fraper aec
jsqa tens qel soit un claire papin, et si
lons voix qe la sope est trop epesse il fat
verser encorre un pet dea, jsqa tens qel
soit bien; pis il le fat faire bolier, un
pet, et sa en le tollient tojor, apres sa,
il fat le passer par un linge, et apres sa
sens serir, por enpeser la sois aec ~
Maniere por faire de flers de sois;
Notez, qand la sois est tres bien peniez, metez la desrre
d ver, bien plas, la grander dn carax de fenette, assez
resonnablement grand, ensite il fat prendre le plas dn cotax,
et prendre la gomme de sois aec, ensite, il fat leparde desrre
la sois aec, et sa assi long tens, qe la sois en soit tres bien mol=
=liez, est grasse; apres sa, il fat le retorner de latre cotez, et
il fat faire de meme; apres sa; il fat le mettre desrre une
seriet, por le faire secher par le vans, et o atrement assi;
ensite il fat le plaqer, et mettre desrre la forme; et le
repasser aec une pierre liqoire;, est le faire secherre pres
la fe, et o bien, desrre une etoe; ensite loterre
de la; et pis coper des flers aec; des tos telle sorte
qe vos volez faire; me il fat tojors garder la
sois preparez a faire des flers aec, dans d papier blan;
de meme assi, la sois qel ne pas encore preparez a
faire des flers; ~~~

Maniere por detindre le cambraij, tain
aec de la gomme-gt, il fat ensieper la
piece de cambraij qasi tote asi grand qe
la piece et, ensite le mollier un pet,
et le froter dans les mains, assez bien, pis
il fat le plonger, et le laer dans de lea
chade, o bien dans la lecie, comme lons
lae le cambraij blan, en changant dea
de temp, en temp, jsqa tant qe le cam=
=braij, soit parfaittement blan, il fat ensieper
la piece de cambraij dex o trois fois por
cette fin; ~~~
Le cambraij tain aec d safran, et de la
gomme-gt, se detain de la meme maniere asi,
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
la Maniere por detaindre le dras incarnate, o incarlacqe;
il fat prendre dex painte de lecie, fait aec de cendre
de vinne, aec, une demie painte, dea de plis o de fontain,
il fat bolier sa ensemble; aec qelqe petit morcax de
dras incarlacqe, qe vos lesez bolier tos jsqa tans qe la tain=
=terre soit bolie or d dras, et qil soit tos detain, ensite il le
fat prendre or d pot de terre, qe vos gardez por cette fin, et
apres aoir presez la lecie deor, il + fat encorre prend un atre morcax
dincarlacqe, et le faire bolier, de la meme [illeg] maniere, me
a chaqe fois qe vos presez la lecie deor, il fat tojors la rejeter
dans le post, il fat continer comme sa, tos jsqa tans qe vos
voiez, qe lincarlacqe ne se detain pls; et qil reste beax; a dont
et la taintrre bonne, a dont, il fat pendre de la gomme, qe vos aez
tranpez, et fonde lespasse de trois fois 24. here, en le tollient de tans,
en tens, estant encorre assez epesse il le fat passer par un for claire
linge, ensite il fat jeter la gomme dans la ditte taintrre, et le leser
bolier ensembles tos jsqa tems qe la sope deien fort epesse, a
dont vos poez vos en serirre, por tracer aec le paincax,

lisez a cette me qand la taintrre
est trop grase, o trop epesse, et o tos
secqe, il fat tojors lamortirre, et le ra=
=longer aec de lea de plis, o de fontainne;. et sa
jsqua tans qe vos voiez qe la taintr et bien

a vos en serirre aec le paincax, por
tracer aec, desr le cambraij, et desrre le papiez;
tote les petit morcax de dras incarlacqe, que les
talliers jette enoie, ils sons bon por sa, il ne pas
nesecaire daoir des grand morcax, ~~

Comme il fat, accomoder les
toilles por faire de flers ~
Apres qe les cambraij, mochelin, et
toilles, sons for bien laez, et bien saichez,
il fat prendre, o faire une belle enpoise
assez epesse, et pis enpaisez votre toilles, o
cambraij, de la meme maniere, comme long ~
enpoise les coiffr, pis il fat pendre les
linge a cordons, estant bien saiqe, il fat
passer la main desr, des dex cot d linge,
por la rendre bien unie, pis les plier aec
la main, de la les mettre dans un papi, il
se fat garder, de ne pas se serirre d
ferre comme lons repasse les linge, ni atres
instrment por cette fin, il fat obserer
cette ordre por totes les atres colers asij.
cette sorte detoilles, ne pis serirre qe
por des flers tote blanche sans estres ~
trasez ~~
Atre cambraij blan, por pooir estre
trasez, il fat prendre d blan damidons,
+ pltot pls, qe moin
atant qil en pis dans une petit clier + aec
tant soit pet de ble dempois, atant qe
vos volez laoir ble; pis il fat prendre la

moitiez dn ver de la colle de poisson, pis
bien demeler, et rompre le blan danpoise, dans la colle, ensite il
fat mettre le brn ble danpoise de dans, et le bien demaler, pis plonger
citot la cambraij dans la soupe, atans qe la sope en soit tos penetrez
dans le cambraij, me tres bien molliez, il faut la bien orir, et preser, et
retorner, et un pet froter, plsiers fois, afin qe la blan, soit bien
pentrez dans la cambraij; de la latacher a corde aec des epeinghe; ~~
me si la corde este de crin, il sfie de la
pendre, en se gardans, qe la bo qil pend
natache pas ensemble, cette ordre doit estre
obserez dans totes les atres coloers. ~

Por faire des toille jonates, por ja=
=semein, et atres flers, il fat mettre
aec ce blan dempois, et colle de poisson;
trois, o qatre gote, de gommegte, ~
Por en faire des rogates il fat
prendre d blan damidons, colle de poisson,
et trois o qatre gote de carmin, ces
sorte de cambraij, ser por faire des eliez
et atres floers, ~~
Les toilles temp se pet verde, long fait
comme deant, en versant qelqe gote de
la boteille, o le vers et dedans, et si
vos volez laoir jonates, vos metez parmij
la colle, et la ver, une gote o dex de
gommegte. ~~
Les cambraij ble se fait aec d brn ble

encorre une atre sorte de palle ble,
por le commancement de bleuse alimon, et
de rononclle blese, bacop mie qe le
palle ble danpois; ~ il faut prendre un + morcax
novax de toille blese, qe lon apelle la tain =
=trre de brges; bien propre, il fat le mettre
un pet trenper dans de lae froide; ensite il
fat le laer qe la rosse, o noir sope en
soit sortie; il fat jeter cette ae la enoie;
pis il fat prendre une atre claire ae;
fraide assi; ensite il fat le laer encorre
une fois dans cette ae; estant bien laez, et
lae tres bien blese, il fat le prendre or de
lae, et le bien tordre; pis, il fat leser cette

ae la, comme sa, sans le remer trois, o
qatre here; pls o moin; ensite il fat
ieter la claire ae enoie, et le fons
garder puis il fat prendre vostre toille, et cambraij;
et la plonger dans une petit partie de cette ae,
si bien que vos ne deez pas preser lea deor; apres
sa, il le fat pendre a corde, estens secqe,
il fat faire encorre un fois de meme; js =
=qa tans qe vos voiez qe la coleur est
comme vos volez laoir, estant saicqe
il fat lanpeser dans la colle de cire;
sans la preser deor, ceporqoij qil nen fat
prendre qnne petit partie de la ditte colle,
afin qe le cambraij en soit tres bien molliez
sans pooir goter, estant pende a corde;

dempoise, et de la colle de poisson, il
fat coper le cambraij dans la longer, de
dex, o trois cars, et la larger, de trois tails,
o une demie car, chaqe piece de cambraij,
o de moselin, doit estre laez piece, a
piece dans la colle, sans prendre pls de colle
qe la piece en soit tous moliez, aec le
ble assi, pis frotez tos dosement le ble dans
le cambraij, et qand il et bien ble, il fat tenier
chaqn un bot dans la main, ensite passer
la main dese, dn bo, a latre, pis le re=
=torner, et en faire de meme; por la rendre
bien unie, ensite vos latachez, o pandez
a corde, mais qand le cambraij et saichez, et
qil ne pas assez ble, il le fat plonger encorre

cambraij, et por faire des alimon, qe lons ap=
=pella archeecqe, comme asij des hiacinte, et
des bleels, &c. ~~~
la colle de cire est
assi bon por faire sa;
et encore mie, qe latre;
Le palle ble se fait de la meme maniere,
mais en place de prendre d brn ble dampois
il fat prendre d palle ble dampois. ~
cette mochelinne, ser por le commencement
des archeecqe
; notez qe la palle ble, fait aec d brn ble
danpoisse, est le pls beax, de tos les atres;
colers;
notez les archeecque son des alimon blese, o violet;

Le brn ble, et le palle ble, por les
archeecqe, etant copez, il les fat tracer
aec d carmin. ~~~
Un atre ble qe long fait serirre por
le desos, des archeecqe, qe long en voie qa=
=sie rien, parceqe la coloers ne vax rien
qoij qel soit belle en apparence, il fat
prendre un cara, o dex, de lecqemose,
qe lons etampe, bien liez dans une bonne
toille, pis le mettre, tremper, un jor et une
nit, pis vos le faite bolier, aec une
pinte edemis dau de plie, pltot moin qe
pls; en presans aec un baton sr la toille
o le ble, et ddans, afin qe tos le ble
en sorte, pis il fat mettre, le cambraij, o
la toilles, dans la sope bolier ensemble,
estent un pet bolie, il la fat prendre
or de la sope, et les pender sr les corde
estant saichez, si elle ne sont point blese
assez, on les pet plonger encorre une fois,
dans la meme sope, et sa plsiers fois
sil en et besoin, estant saicqe, on les
met en colle de poisson, o en colle de cire,

Por faire encorre ponsa; por faire les alimon,
et le rononclle; il fat prendre, trois ecaille de
molet plainne de mien roge, il le fat bien froter
aec un morca de mabre, desr d mabre o d grez;
estant bien frotez; il fat le jeter dans un ver, o la
troisieme partie dn ver de la colle de cire, aec une
ecaille de molet plainne de vermilion; il fat bien
le tolier, et meler ensemble; ensite il fat jeter,
le cambraij blan dans la colle; et le bien torner, et
preser, et retorner dans les mains, en le frotent une
pet, afin qe la teintre soit bien penetrez, et qe
le cambraij, mochelinne, et toille soit bien roge;
apres il sa, il fat preser la colle, et taintrre
deor, si bien qel reste resonnablement bien mo=
=liez, pis il fat le pendre a gerniez; et estant secqe,
la toille, cambraij, et mochelinne; estant copez par
felles, il fat mettre un claire cermain desr; qe
vos voiez estre tres belle coler a vostre volontez;

Notez si vos voiez qe la taintr est trop epesse,
aec un ver de colle de cire; il en fat prendre da=
=antage, tos jsqa tans qe la sope soit bien
Notez qand vos volez faire moin, a dont il fat
prendre d vermillion, et de la mien a vostre volontez, et le
bien demeler dans la colle de cire; ensite prendre tote a la
fois ce qe vos aez preparez por taindre; et la jeter assitot
dans la colle, o atrement die dans la sope; il fat tres pet
froter, me en la place de sa; il fat le tres bien le preser, et
retorner, lorire; et apres sa, encore le preser, et retor=
=ner, tos jsqa tems qe la taintr soit bien penetrez dans
le cambraij; a la fin si vos voiez, qe vos aez trop de
sope, o qe le cambraij est trop moliez; il fat mettre
encore qelqe piece de cambraij dedans, si bien qe vos ne ~
deez rien preser deor; il fat encore preser cela tote ensem=
=bles assi; afin de le faire penetrer dans la taintr assi;
Me si vos voiez tote a contrairre, qe vos naez pas
de colle, et de la taintrre assez por la cantitez qe vos aez
commencez a taindre; a dons; il + fat prendre tote letoffe deor,
ensite verser de la colle, dans la telle, et il fat demeler de la
taintrre encore dedans, apres sa jetter tote la masse dedans;
et faire comme cij deant; me la colle, et le cambraij, doit estre chade

Le ble por les floers, qe lons appelle
des areniez, se fait aec de la cendre dan=
=gleter, de la meme maniere qe le ble dan=
pois, me le ble de la cendre dangleter, ne doit
pas estra frotez dans la toille si for qe le
ble dampois, parceqe la coler et pls finne,
et qil sfie, qe le cambraij a la coloer de
ce ble, ~~~
Por en faire de roge il fat prendre
d vermilion, et de la colle de cire,:
la toilles copez, par foelles, il fat mettre un
claire cermin desur,: la colle de poisson est
asij bonne, me aec la colle de cire, la cermin
et pls facille a tracer, il fat dans la dit
sope, froter les cambraij, comme long fait ~
aec les cendre dangleter, cette toille ser ~
por faire des rononclle, allimone, et con=
=stantinobble ~~~
Les toilles verde se fait, aec de la colle
de cire, et d ver de la boteille, sans blan
dampoise; la colle de poisson est asi bonne,
me le cambraij saichez, il le fat plonger
encorre une foie dans cette colle; parceqe
le ver lamegrie trop, me la colle de cire

il sfie aec la premiere foie, et si
vos volez laoir jonnates, il fat mettre
parmi la colle, et la ver qelqe gote de
la gommegte, cettes sorte de mochelinne,
&c ser por la commencement des rononclle, et
allimon, &c. ~~~
Por tindre la couler des jonqille, il
fat prendre la groser d'ne grosse noie,
de la gommegte, aec un pet de safran
entiere, sans estre etemp, qil fat
mettre tramper dans un pet da, il
sfie qe la soit dans le petit post ~
later de la gommegte; et le safran dans
un atre petit post; le leser bien tirer sa
coloers, aec un pet da chade; la
gommegte estant tos fonde, il fat
verser la moitiez, dans la colle de pois=
=son, la cantitez de la moitiez d'n ver,
assaniron, pis il fat prendre un
pet de la sope de ce safran, qe vos
tollerez tos ensemble, dans la colle, en=
=site, il fat prendre le cambraij, et ~
laer une piece, dans la dit sope, por
voire si la coloer et a votre agreation,
me si elle et trop hat jonne, il fat

ij mettre de la gommegte, dans la meme
sope, jsqa tent qel soit bien, et ~
qand la coloer et trop pal jonne; il fat
ij mettre pls de sope de safran, et faire
comme cij deant, comme asij aec un pet
de colle; Por un esqelein de gommegte, aec
por six liars, de safran, fait une belle
coloers, il fat mettre aussi pour deux liar oln
etanpez, et le bien, rompe, et tolier ensembles, aec de lae; ~
Por le palle jonne, il ne fat prendre
qe de la gommegte, aec de la colle de
poisson; me si le jonne est por tracer, il
fat prendre de la colle de cire; parce=
=qe le cermin, se trace pls facillement
sr le cambraij, aec cette sorte de colle.
notez, qe la gomgte, et la sope de safran ensemble est belle
sans oln assi, de meme la gomgte +seulle sans oln dedans, elle est pls prre;
Notez, totes les coloers jonne, et jonnate,
comme asij la coloers roge de vermilion,
qand ce por tracer, il fat tojor lampeser
aec la colle de cire, ~~~
Le cermin se demelle aec un pet da de
plis, o de fontaine, pis,ilfat le leser
tremper un jor, et une nit, aant de
senserire por tracer; le cermin doit estre
rompe, o demelez, dans une ecail dostre, o
bien dans un ver, for plas, aec la valers dne

petit clier da, pltot moin qe pls, ~
me qand cette ea et qasie tos tracez,
il fat ij verser encorre qelqes gote
da, et ainsij continer jsqa temp qe
le carmin soit tos tracez, chaqe fois
qe vos plonge le peinca, dans le carmin,
il ne fat pas le plonger trop aant, ~
afin de ne pas for remer ~ le fons;
par ~ ainsij le carmin, vos sera pls pro=
=fitable. ~~~~
Por tracer violet, il fat demeler dans
un petit poet, o dans une ecaille dostre,
o bien, dans un plae ver, de cendre dan=
=gleter, aec qatre, o cinq, gote de claire
gomme, le ble estant bien demelez aec la

asij d papiez, comme lons pintr les floers,
il fat plonger le paincax dans la teintre
en remant un pet le font, afin qe
le ble, donne sa teintre; mais qand la
sope et qasie tos tracez, et qe dans le

font la teintre ne pas encorre tote ~
usez, il fat ij mettre qelqe gote da,
aec un gote de gomme ~ ; me non pas a
chaqe foie qe vos ij metez de la; me

se trace pas bien, car qand ce ble a trop

gates lagreation d ble; apres qe le ble
et tracez, et bien saichez; sr le cambraij
trasaij; il fat ij tracer sr ledit ble un
claire carmin. ~~~ por les rosse,
Por tindre coloer de rosse; il fat
prendre un cartron de sanflor, qe lons
met dans un petit sac, de toille blanche;
ensite on le met tremper dans un sea
dea de plis, o de fontainne; asitot on

=per, depis cinq hers edemie, d soir, jsqa

changent da; des tems, en tems; et sa sans

tordre le petit sac, me sellement le preser,
un pet, aec la main, lea deor; et qand
lea demere claire, sest signe qe le
sanflor, et laez assez; la derniere foij,
qe vos lotez de lea, il fat bien ~
preser, et tordre le petit sac, afin qe
+ si vos volez
lea en sorte totes entierement. me + il fat
garder cette derniere rainsr, sans le remer, tos jsqa tans qe

cela dans la premiere rainsr ~~ + et moin encorre
Ensite on le tire d sac, et on le met
dans une grand terrine bien propre; il

pertris, comme lons fait le pain, lespasse
dn cardher, pis il fat le remettre dans
le petit sac, por le passer, dans une

Notez, aant de verser le sanflorre dans
le petit sacqe, afin de le torde pls facille=
=ment, il fat prendre dans une main une

Notez, si vos aez de la lecie un pet trop, une

qil a estez presez la sope deor, et

fois coler; apres qe vos aez laez

jeter, dans la sope de la premiere cou=

meme assi, tote la rainsrre: ~~
si bien, qe cette coler la, ne

atre colers de rosse, assi; ~
il fat le bien laer. dans la rainsrre; ~

___, il fat le partager entre fois, sans repeter, ou trois, entre et __,

terrine bien propre il fat tordre le
sac, le pls fort qe lon pet, afin qe

Ensite lons prepare, asitot une atre
terine, aec un pet d vinaigre de vin

=tre dans le vinaigre, a meme temp, qe

ses mains dans le vinaigre, aant qe la
personne qi a moliez les cambraij dans le
vinaigre, li donne la masse, entre les main,
Laient rece, elle plonge asitot, tote a
~ la foie le cambraij dans la dit sope;
il fat bien le laer, et decarpilier, et

sa dne main leger, asi vite qe lon
pe, jsqa temp qe les cambraij soit bien
roge, et bien penetraij dans la teintre, pis
on le lae piece, a piece, un pet, et on le ~

pis ons le jette dans le verge piece, a piece, il fat le bien

Ensite on les jettes dans un terine, preparez
aec trois pinte dea, por les rincer, un piece

Maniere om te verglden, met godt, ofte siler.
het geene datmen brneeren wilt, tsij godt,
ofte siler, moet voor eerst den gront doen,
met stercken lijm, drooge sijnde leght daen
een laeghe lijm met wit cerse, onderhodende
altijdt dat ghij de tweede laeghe noijt en leght,
ten sij dat de eerste gheheel drooghe is, ende en
leght het noijt te drooghen daer het groote sonne
maeckt, en leght het wit niet te dicke, men
moet het legghen tot 9. oft 10. keeren, sijer=
=et alsdaen, en maecket wel effen met een
wlfs tant, oft met water van spaensche
seepe, ende vrift het daer mede tot dat het
effen is, doen moet men ten minsten eenen
dagh laeten rsten, eer ghij het gaet verglden,
ofte versileren, Maer onder het got, doetmen
de twee laest keeren met lijm, wat witte
cerse en orannie verweijen, om den gront,
godt coler te hebben ~~~~
Gal van een palinck, in wat brandewijn ghe=
smolten, is goet voor te verlichten, godt, oft siler,
inde naervolghende colers, groen, swart, grise,
en geele,
het doet de verweijen vloeijen, en maecht dat sij
niet afschelferen; dit klienne cantiteijdt van het
gal van eennen palinck en is maer om te traceren
met eennen peinceelle op beeldekens, maer als sij grooter

werchken maecken, soo moetmen grooter
cantiteijdt van gal, ende brandewijn neemen,
nootert, als ghij maer lichte wercken en wielt
maecken, met 4. oft 5. gronden te leeghtgen
tis al ghenogh; ~~~~
nota, dat den palinck gal, maer en
is om te verlichten, maer niet om
te traceren met een peinceel op
beeldekens, daer + + tou is den brandewijn
wel alleen; als oock een drepelken, oft
twee reghen, oft fontainne waters, dit is het best, om
te doen inde godt, oft selere shelpe, en daer mede
te verghlden, ende te traceren met den peinceel; maer
om te verghlden met schm godt, oft selere; den
gront moet magre naet ghemaeckt worden, met wijtte van
heijren wel ghesleeghen, maer oer al wel naet, daer
naer, leghtmen daer op, het godt, oft selere schm;
finne oft grof, men det het to, met een kliennen
brockskens spongie; van te voor wel gewaeschen;
daer naer vijt ghedet in eennen docken, ende daer
naer, daer mede verglden; ende als de spongie wat
te droghen worde, doetmen als voor; ~~
Nota, als het met olie is, men neemt ghebrant
olie, ende men machket naet met die olie, ende
selere, oft godt schm daer op; ende men
doet met de spongie als voor; ~~

JESUS, MARIA, AUGUSTINUS.
PUIS que lEsprit Saint permet de loer, aprs la mort les personnes, qui meritent
de l'tre; il est trop juste, de rendre un devoir si legitime la memoire de la
REVERENDE MERE
MERE ADRIENE TERESE DE MALDEGHEM,
Chanoinesse Reguliere de lOrdre de St. Augustin, qui mourut Tournay dans le Monastere de Ntre Dame de Sion
le 28. de lan 1680. parmy les prieres & regrez de ses cheres Consoeurs, aprs avoir re les SS. Sacremens de lEglise
avec autant de piet, que de resignation aux volontez Divines. Age de 65. ans, & Professe de 48. une vie aussi Re-
ligieuse qua t la sienne l'espace de tant d'annes, ne pouvoit promettre une fin moins Heureuse: la grace per-
fectionant les avantages tires de son Illustre Extraction, lavoit rendu un exemple anim de toutes les vertus,
& un sujet tout fait pour le gouvernement des autres; ce qui a paru avec clat en toute sa Vie, & dans les fon-
ctions quelle a exerces de Matresse des Novices; de Sou-prieure & de Prieure avec cette sage, prudente, ferme
& Sainte Conduite qui en a t Inseparable: MAIS, aprs que Saint Paul dit; quoy que sa conscience ne
luy reprocht rien, quil ntoit pourtant pas Justifi, quelle Saintet se peut delivrer de cette crainte salutaire des
Jugemens de Dieu! Ainsi quoy que nous ayons tant dlndices de son eternelle felicit, lon implore les Sacrifices
& prieres; Afin que si la Justice divine exigeoit delle des restes que le Purgatoire dt encore expier, elle puisse
tre au pltt en tat de joir des chastes embrassemens de sn celeste Epoux, Ce sont ces offices charitables que
lon demande des Communautez Religieuses, & de tous les fidels.
Requiescat in pace.

Mr joris Drogist vercopt fernabocken
houdt dat heel goedt is om root papier
te schilderen men doet dit als volght
voor twee stuijvers of vijf groote van
dit houdt navolgens den plas dat men wilt
maeken en om het sekerste nemt maer
Delft hier van; en doet het in een pot met
een kanne of drie pinten regen water
laete het wat trecken en dan een alf uren coken
of wat meer dan een stuck rooden allun kloppen
fijn maer moet eerst in een schotel of panne
smilten apart maer moet verstaen dat dit niet root
schindt maer is wit maer woort soo genomt en bij
den voorseijden oock verkoght als thout soo lange ge=
suddert heeft dan giet gij dat sop van den allun in den
ersten pot en om roert het met een stocktien dan woort
het heel root en laet het wat tsaemen sudderen giet dan wat
sop in een potteken en als het coel is nemt wit papier leght het op

een tafel begint te schilderen maer moet sleghte
of jets dat niet bederven can onder leggen en jder
bladt op een cordeken hangen alwaert maer een
pack cordeken dan laeten drogen en soo continueren
tot dat het root genogh is naer uw gouste alwaert
tot ses a seven mal wilt gij het blinckende
hebben gaet het eens over met wijt van heyeren fijn
geslegen dit sop is oock goedt om sijde root te maeken
besonderlijck witten gront of gelve maer moet eerst suijver
gewasschen sijn of linten maer moet een weijnigh hier
in kocken tis oock goet om wit hout root te maeken
en als het root genog is met wasch gevreven dat blinckt
en is gelijck Bois dacasou de gront van dit can meer
als eens dienen met ander waeter en nog weijnig hout
daer in en allun is wederan goet sap
maer de groote van den allum soo een dobbelen
bocket jmers het leert sijn selven

regen waeren en stelt de looghe en giet de
looghe claer af in eene nieuwen arder pot
en nemt t root laecken en doet t in de looge
tt t oversopt is, en stelt den pot wel gedeck
met een arde pot decksel savons van te voor
in den lauwen oven en laet t trecken tt
sanderdagh ten zy furen nemt als dan
den selven pot en set hem op een contoor
met vier en laet t een ure lanck koken en t laet t
geduerigh om keeren met een nieuwe pot
lepen dat t niet en b[r]andt, nemt als dan

in tweeden pot en al t sop daer uijt synde nemt
een alf pinte wijn azijn en roert dien lanck

Manire om rood pampier
te verwen
Doet een onse pottasschen in
eenen aerden pot, kokt dan
een stoop regen waeter en|
giet dat al kockende op de
pottasschen, laet dit stille
staen tot saenderdags giet dan
stillekens sonder roeren de claere
looge af in eenen aenderen pot,
die suyver is, nemt dan een kanne
van dese looge stelt die te kocken
en nemt een pont rood lacken
doet dit in een suyver pot en als
de looge kokt giet die op het
laecken, laet dit wat trecken
op het vier van tijd tot tijd
keerende het laeken als het al
wel dordronken is stelt het af
en laet het wat verkoelen steld
dan de aender kanne looge op het
vier laet het kooken douwd dan
het laeken uijt soo stijf als gij
kont en als de looge kokt doet
dan het laeken daer in, keert
en wend het wel laet een quar-
-tier koken laet het dan wat
verkoelen douwt het wederom
uijt, doet dan al het sop bij een
stelt dit op het vier doet daer
een susijn witten alluijn in
laet dit een weijnig koken het
moet wel geschuijmt, worden, ze
en moght het schuijm niet wegh
worpen want daer komt noch
goede verwe van, doet dan wat
witten wijnsteen in eenen pot
en giet de kokende verwe daer op,
als ze siet dat daer noch schuijm
op komt nemt het af, en doet
niet bij het aender schuijm laet
het dan twee a drij daegen staen
sonder roeren, giet dan al stille-
-kens de verwe af, en siet of den
gront vuijl is offer swaerte brox-
-kens in sijn, alser in sijn ten
is niet goet, als den gront suij-
-ver is doet het bij de verwe, stelt
dan werderom op het vier, als het
violet is, het is dater geen wijn-
-steen genoegh in is, ook alser
te veel wijnsteen in is, is het
te bleek doet dan wat stijf blome
of ameldonk in eenen pot brekt

die met het koudt sop dat van
het schuijm komt en als de ver-
-we kokt doet die dan in den pot
daer de blome in is al roerende
dat de blomme niet en klontert
als de verwe te violet is doet dan
nog wat wijnsteen bij de blomme
tot dat ze siet dat het schoon
van coleur is, noteert dat de verwe
niet en mag gestopt zijn ook en
kan niet lang bewaeren, maer
kan erkokt zijn als sij violet
geworden is laet die een weijnig
koken doet dan wat wijnsteen in
een aender pot, giet de verwe daer
op doet het schuijm af en als
het nog te violet is doet'er nog
wat wijnsteen bij tot dat ze siet
dat het schoon is en alsser geen
schuijm op en komt moet het
laeten staen tot dat het geson-
-ken is, giet het dan stillekens
af siet op den gront goet is als
vooren, en doet het in eenen pot
laet het tot kooken kommen
nemt wat blome als vooren
geseijt is, hoe drooger de plaet-
-se is daer de verwe staet hoe
beter sij kan bewaeren,
men kan daer mede ook schil-
-deren en als men geel bleek
wilt hebben moet men wat
regen watter daer bij doen
~~~~~~~

Maniere om Root pampier te verwen
men moet eene once potasschen doen in een
suyveren aerden pot die niet vet en is, en
kokt alsdan een stoop regen water giet dat
al kokende op den potasschen, laet dit stille
staen tot sanderdaeghs giet dan stillekes
sonder roeren de klaere looghe af in een
ander pot die suyver is, neemt dan een kanne
van dese looghe, stelt die te koken, doet een
pont root laecken in eenen suyveren pot, en
als de looghe kokt giet die op het laeken,
laet dit wat staen trecken op het vier, van
tyt tot tyt keerende het laeken, als het al
wel doordronken is steld het af en laet wat
verkoelen steld dan de ander looghe te koken
dauwt het laeken in den pot daer het in is,
soo styf als ge kont en als de looghe kokt doet
dit laeken daer wederom in keert en went
het wel laet het een 'quartier heurs koken
laet wat verkoelen douwt het wederom uyt
soo styf als t mogelyk is, doet dan al het sop
by een en steld dit op het vier doet daer een
sisein witten alluyn laet dit een weynig
koken, als het begint te koken moet het
schuym afgenomen worden, maer en moght
het schuym niet weg worpen want daer komt
noch goede verwe van, doet dan wat witten
wynsteen in eenen pot, en giet de kokende
verwe daer op, alsser noch schuym op komt
neemt het af doet het by het ander schuym
laet de verwe twee a dry daeghen staen
sonder ^ roeren en giet die al stillekes af siet oft de
gront vuyl is offer swarte brocxkes in syn
en doet die uyt als den gront schoon en suyver
doet het by de verwe steld dan wederom op het
vier als het te violet is het is datter geen wyn=
steen genoeg in en is oock alser te vele wynsteen
in is dan is het te bleek doet dan wat styfbloeme
in een pot breekt die met het kout sop dat van
het schuym gekomen is en als de verwe kokt
doet die dan in den pot daer de bloeme in
gebroken is al roerende dat de bloeme niet en
klontert als de verwe te violet is doet dan nog
wat wyn steen by de bloeme tot dat ul siet dat
het schoon van couleur is

Om Roose Coler te Verwen moet men nemen een groote handt-vol
fijn linwaet ende dan neemt men een alf pont sofloers de welcke
soflers gedaen moet worden in een linwaete saeckjen ende dan leght
men die sofloors die in het saecxkien ^ is in reghen waeter ses of seven ren
te weecke, en dan somwijlen eens het saecxkien omgekeert in het water
en als het langhe genoegh geweeckt heeft dan moet men het saecx=
=kien wasschen sonder open de doen soo langhe tot dat den sack root
wort; N om de looghe te maecken, moet ghij nemen wijngaert hot
en dat verbrandt tot asschen van welcke asschen men moet nemen
een pot vol en die asschen doetmen in eenen ketel met twee potten
reghen waeter en alsoo laet et een aleene alf re koken, en dan neemt
den ketel van het vier en laet et sijncken want de looghe moet
claer sijn; en dan begint te verwen, ende dan leght het sackxjen.
met sofloors in een schotel ende schdt daer over een cleen bier
glaeskien ontrent alf vol looghe schdt het over het sackxkien ende
wascht het sackxkien daer mede ende vrijnght dan het sackxken
alf ijt, ende doet dan het claerste linwaet daer in en als het nat is
dan dow-et ijt, dan neemt een scholtelken azijn ende doet dat stckxken
linwaet inden azijn ontrent een glasken dan dow-et ijt neemt weder het
selve stckxken linwaet dat inde verwe heeft geweest, doet het weder[-]
-om in die selve verwe soo dow-et ijt en doet het wederom in dien
selven azijn dan dow-et ijt soo werpt dan dien azijn ijt en doet
dan weder s[cho]onen azijn in het schotelken, en werpt dan oock ijt de
verwe, soo vrijnght dat sackxken voors ijt, dan neemt dat voorgaende
stck dat noch geverwt is en doet 'et weer daer in, soo dan dow-et
weer ijt en leght-et weder in den azijn, soo dow-et weer ijt dan
is dat stck roodt genoegh; soo moet ghij weder een ander claer stckxken
linwaet nemen, en leght-et inde verwe en dan weder in den azijn gelijck
als vooren; en als de verwe claer wort dan werpse ijt; en leght dan het
sackxken inde schotel giet dan weder een half glasken looghe over het
sackxken, en dan vrijnght het daer mede, doen vrijnght het sackxken half
ijt, en begint dan wederom te verwen, op die selve maniere als vooren,
en als ghij bemerckt dat daer gheen verwe meer ijt en comt dan claer
soo moet ghij dan ophoden van te verwen, dan moet ghij het roodt linwaet
wasschen, met wat spaensche seepe, maer ghij moet de seepe in een doeckx[=]
=ken doen, en slaet dan het doeckxken met de seepe daer in het water, soo
moet ghij dan stck voor stck wasschen, in een heemer, en dan met schoon
water gespoelt, soo vrijnget ijt en leght het in een schotet [corr: schotel] en doet dan
azijn daer over soo laet het een geheelen nacht staen daer in, sanderdaeghs
vrijnght-et dan ijt, en leght het dan te drooghen op een sargie en dat in
het doncker; en als-et dan drooghe is moet ghij het stijven met wit stijf[=]
=sel, ghij moet nemen een vierendeel van een pondt en dan laeten kodt worden
soo moet ghij dan het linwaet stijven, en dan ijt malcander doen oock op een
sargie en dat int doncker laeten soo drooghen;
N om witte roosen te maecken soo moet ghij nemen wit linwaet en doet
het in het seep water daer het roodt linwaet in gewasschen is geweest,
en door het claer water gespoelt, maer en doet het in gheenen azijn, maer
stijvet als vooren,

om groen Papier te maeken
Nemt het groen van siederi het jeugdigste al de rebben
uyt gedaen dan gestampt in Mortier dan uyt
gevrongen en dan wederom gestampt toe drye mal
toe, nemt dan spaens groen en doet het in het sop
tot dat het gesmoltens is, doet daer soo veele in als
dat het ue wilt groene hebben hoe meer groen hoe
ooger couleur ook een weinig wijn steen van tyd
tot tyd roeren tot dat het heel gesmolten is, nemt
dan het papier en legt het op een tafel of bert, nemt
dan een schilder c[ou]s[t]elken en strick het daer over
den eenen kant gedaen sijnde ank het te drogen
en wel droge synde doet dan en anderen kant en
dat soo dikmals tot dat het groene genoeg is
volgens ue gouste d nemt dan wit van eyeren en
strikt het daer over om den glans te geven als
het wel drooge is

w

Voor een alf pont spans groen
men nempt twee kannen reghen
water, en doet daer in, een alf
vierendeel witte wijnsteen, en
een teenne lepel gestamten oln

moet vercoken tot op den helft,
en men doet het sap groen daer
in als het maer bloet waerme
en is

en vriest dat an den kant

daer niet te veele in doen, ghij moet

nota het pampier dat ghij daer toe
ghebruckt, moet fijn en ghesloten sijn
en dat pampier moet gepaept sijn al
eenen kant met witten stijf pap die
warme is, en niet dicke, ghij moet den
pap wel en effen in v[e]rwen met eenen
sochten bustel, anght dan te droeghen
en als het wel drooghe is leght het dan te
passen om dat het soude effen commen
nemt dan uwe groen verwe, en
een deel van een spontie om alsoo
u pampier te verwen, al den
gepapten kant eerst, maer naer den
eersten en 2 keer, moet dat met een
lijcht handt doen en magher dat
het niet vloijdt, als ghij u blat
pampier met een lijcht handt over
gaen hebt en sijnde datter noch
striepen sijn die ghij over geschreckelt
hebt en moght daer niet meer an

kommen want ghij soudt meer af

Maniere om afschen van wingaert ranken te macken
men brant die, op eenen suijveren hert, sonder ander afschen in
te mengelen, n gebrant sijnde, men doet tvier en dafschen
al te saemen in eenen schlechten aerden pot, die men van tijdt
tot tijdt opsteeckt, tot dat al verteirt is.
om looghe van wingaert ranken afschen te macken
neemt drije hants=vellen afschen met twee handen, en 7. of 8.
pinten regen of fonteijne waeter, laet die koken tot op 4. of 5.
pinten, wort die gekockt in eene sijver marmijte, als die vant
vier genomen wort, moet gegoten sijn in eenen aerden pot, die
tot geen ander sacken gedient en heeft als om roosen te verwen,
laetende dafschen soo veel alst mogelijck is op den gront van de
marmijte, des anderdags men giet de looghe door eenen doeck
in eenen anderen pot, nochtans voorsichtig sonder den gront te
roeren, de looge is dan bequaem om te gebrijcken om roose-koler
te verwen, soo als hier volgt
neemt een vierendeel of alf pont sanflor, doet het in een wit
linwaten sacxken versekert toe gebonden, stelt het te wecken
in regen of fonteijne waeter, men wast een weijnig het sanflor
tselve twee keeren van waeter veranderende; en dan laeten wecken
van den vijf heren en-alf savonts tot den vijf uren en-alf smor
gens. en dan wort het gewaschen, en van tijdt, tot tijdt, van
waeter verandert, tot dat het klaer wort, den sack en magh
niet gevrongen sijn, maer ijtgedogen met de handen, ten sij
den laetsten keer, dan moet het sacxken soo sterck uijtgevrongen
sijn alst mogelijck is

daer naer men treckt het sanfloer ijt den sack, en doet het
in eenen grooten platten pot, en alst al wel van een gepluckt
is men sproeijt er en weijnig regen of fonteijne waeter
over. dan giet me[n] int sanflor een pinte looghe gemachts
van afschen van wijngaert ranken; dan woort de pot ge=
deckt met eenen anderen van de selve groote, om dat hij
locht en sode vatten stelt hem in een dijster plaetse
uel noch een deckkleet daer op, en alsoo laeten trecken
2. heren, en moet dan gekne[uz]t worden een quaertier lanck
men degt het met hantsvollen ijt, als men niet meer
nemen en kan giet de reste wederom in den sack, die ijt
gevrongen wort, in eenen suijveren pot, men bereijt terstont
eenen anderen pot met wat asijn van witte win, daer de stoffe
in wort nat gemackt, wel doordroncken sijnde, men neemt die
altesaemen, geeft die in handen van de persoone die tsanfloer
gekne'et en ijtgevrongen heeft; welcke geheel masse haette
lijck in de verwe steekt, de selve wel waschen en'van een
trecken, met eene lichte hant soo gaw alst mogelijck is.
de stoffe haer coler hebbende, wort wederom van stck tot stk
gewaschen naer die wel ijtgedogen thebben, steekt ^ die in verjis
naer alsvooren uijt gedowen sijnde, wort gespoelt in drie of 4.
potten vervolgende te vooren bereijt met 2. of 3. pinten schoon
regen of fonteine waeter; waer naer men eenige stcken stoffe
wascht daert teeste coler in gespoelt is, twelcke dient
voor bleek coler, en wort dan samen gedroogt op den solder.

Way for melting silk gum, or other-
wise said tragacanth gum;
One takes for this one patar of the said gum; it
is necessary to put it to soak, in a half pint
of rainwater, better more than less. One needs to
leave it like that for two days, then one needs to take
a spoon and stir it well, and hit it with it
until such time it becomes a clear glue-pap, and if
one sees that the soup is too thick, one needs
to pour in a bit of water, until such time that it
is good; then one needs to make it boil, a
bit, and that while stirring it still. After that,
one needs to pass it through a cloth, and after that,
use it to starch silk with it.
Way to make silk flowers
Note: when the silk is very well peniez, put it on top
of glass, very flat, the size of one window pane,
reasonably big enough. Next, one needs to take the flat side of a knife,
and take the silk gum with it. Next, one needs to spread it on top
of the silk with it, and that also for a long time, that the silk becomes very well
moistened, and fatty. After that, one needs to turn it over, and
one needs to do the same. After that, one needs to put it on top of a
towel, to let it dry in the wind, and or otherwise also.
Next one needs to apply it, and put it on top of the form; and
go over it with a pierre liquoire. And dry it near to
the fire, and or else above a stove. Next, remove it
from there. And then cut flowers from it, of all kinds
that you want to make. But one needs always to keep
silk prepared for making flowers between white paper.
The same also for silk that is not yet prepared for making flowers.

Way to undye cambric dyed with gamboge
One needs to tie up the
piece of cambric [to a rod?] quasi all as large as
the piece and, next to wet it a bit,
and rub it between the hands, well enough, then
one needs to plunge it and wash it in hot water,
or else in lye, like one
washes white cambric, changing the water
from time to time, until such that the
cambric becomes perfectly white. One needs to tie up
the piece of cambric two or three times for
this end.
Cambric, dyed with saffron and
gamboge, is undyed in the same manner also
The way to undye crimson or incarlacque fabric
One needs to take two pints of lye, made from vine
ashes, with a half pint of rainwater or fountain water.
One must boil that together with some small pieces of
crimson fabric, which you all let boil until such that the
dye becomes boiled out of the fabric and it becomes all undyed. Next one
needs to take it out of the earthenware pot, which you keep for this use, and
after having pressed the lye out, one + needs to take yet an other piece
of incarlacque and make it boil in the same manner. But
each time that you press the lye out, one needs always to re-cast
it into the pot. One needs to continue like that all until such that you
see that the incarlacque does not undye further and that it remains beautiful. A dont
is the dye good, a dont one needs to take the gum that you have
soaked and melted for a space of 24 hours. In stirring from time
to time, being still rather thick, one needs to pass it through a very white
cloth. Next one needs to throw the gum in the said dye and let it
boil all together until such time that the soup becomes very thick, a
dont you can use it to draw with a paintbrush.

read at this But when the dye
is too fatty, or too thick, and or too
dry, one needs always to amortirre [quench/temper?] and
stretch it out with rainwater or fountain water. And that
until such that you see that the dye is good

for you to use with the paintbrush, to
draw with, on cambric, and on paper.
All the little pieces of crimson fabric, which the
tailors throw aside, they are good for that. It is not
necessary to have large pieces.

How one needs to accommodate cloths to make flowers
After cambrics, muslins, and
cloths are very well washed and well dried,
one needs to take, or make, a nice starch
fairly thick, and then starch your canvases or
cambrics in the same manner, just as one
starches coiffures. Then one needs to hang the
cloth by cords. Being well dry, one needs
to pass the hand over it, on both sides of the cloth,
to render it very uniform, then fold them by
hand; from there, put them in a paper. One
needs to keep oneself from using the
iron, as one [commonly] passes over cloths, nor other
instruments for this end. One needs to observe
this command for all other colors too.
This sort of canvas can only serve
for completely white flowers without being
drawn upon.
Another white cambric, to be able to be
drawn upon
One needs to take starch white,
as much as can fit in a small spoon, better more than less, with
as much as can be of starch blue, as much as
you would like to have blue. Then one needs to take

half a glass of fish glue, then
mix well and break the starch white into the glue. Next one
needs to put the starch brown-blue in it, and mix it well. Then plunge
the cambric immediately into the soup, until the soup becomes completely penetrated
into the cambric but very well wet. One needs to open it well, and press, and
turn it over, and rub it a bit, many times, so that the white becomes well
penetrated into the cambric. From there, attach it to a cord with pins.~~
but if the cord is made of horse hair, it is enough to
hang it, taking care that the end from which it hangs
does not attach itself together. This command must be
observed for all other colors.
To make yellowish cloths for
jasmine and other flowers, one needs to put
with this starch white and fish glue
three or four drops of gamboge
To make some reddish ones
One needs
to take starch white, fish glue,
and three or four drops of carmine. This
kind of cambric is used to make carnations
and other flowers
Cloths of this sort can be green
One makes them
as above, by pouring a few drops from
the bottle in which there is green. And if
you want to have yellowish color, you put throughout
the glue and the green one drop or two of
gamboge.
Blue cambric is made with starch brown-blue

Yet another kind of pale blue
for the beginning of blue alimon and
blue ranunculus, much better than
starch pale-blue; ~
One needs to take a piece [of]
new blue cloth, which one calls the
dye of Bruges, very clean. One needs to put
it to soak for a bit in cold water. Next one
needs to wash [until?] only the red or black soup
removes itself. One needs to throw this water away,
then one needs to take another clear water,
cold also. Next one needs to wash it once
more in this water. Being well washed and
the water being very blue, one needs to take it out of
the water and wring it out well. Next, one needs to leave this

water there like that, without stirring it, for three or
four hours, more or less. Next, one needs
to throw the clear water away and keep the bottom.
Then one needs to take your cloth and cambric
and plunge it into a small part of this water
so well that you shouldnt press the water out. After
that, one needs to hang it from a cord. Being dry,
one needs to do the same thing again until
the moment that you see that the color is
as you want to have it. Being dry,
one needs to starch it in hide glue
without pressing it out. This is why one needs
to take only a small amount of the said glue
so that the cambric becomes very well wetted
without dripping once being hung by a cord.

and fish glue. One
needs to cut the cambric in the length of
two or three quarters and the width of three tailes [full sizes?]
or a half square. Each piece of cambric
or muslin must be washed piece by
piece in the glue without taking more glue
than that needed for the piece to be completely wet with the
blue too. Then rub the blue very gently into

each one by the end in the hand and next pass

again, and so forth to make it
very even. Next, you attach it or hang it
by cord. But if the cambric is dry and

once more in the same soup, and do as

cambrics and[=are?] for making alimon, which one

one needs to take starch pale-blue. ~
This muslin is used for the beginning
of archbishops; note that pale blue is made with
starch brown-blue
[and] is the most beautiful of all the other
colors
Note: archbishops are blue or violet alimon;

The brown-blue and pale blue for
archbishops, once cut, one needs to trace
them with carmine.
Another blue that one uses for
the underside of archbishops, which one sees
hardly at all because the colors are not worth anything
even though they are beautiful in appearance.
One needs to take a square or two of lacmus
that one pounds, well bound in a good
cloth, then put it to soak for one day and one
night. Next, you boil it with a
pint and a half of rainwater, better too little than
too much. Pressing the cloth with a stick
where it is blue, and inside, so that all of the blue
leaves it. Then one needs to put the cambric or
the cloths in the soup to boil together.
Being boiled a little, one needs to take it
out of the soup and hang it over cords.
Being dry, if they are plainly not blue
enough, one can plunge them again
in the same soup, and that several times
if there is need. Being dry, one
puts them in fish glue or hide glue.

For making more pansy; for making alimon,
and ranunculus; one needs to take, three mussel shells
full of mien rouge [my red? Same red?], one needs to rub it well
with a piece of marble, on top of some marble or some gres [sandstone?];
being well rubbed; one needs to throw it in a glass, or the
third part of a glass, of the hide glue, with a
mussel shell full of vermillion, one needs to
stir it well, and to mix it together; next on needs to throw
the white cambric into the glue, and turn it well, and
press it well, and return it in the hands, rubbing it a
little, in order that the dye will be well penetrated, and that
the cambric, muslin; and toile will be a good red;
after that, one needs to squeeze the glue, and dye
within, so well that it stays reasonably well wetted,
then one needs to hang in the attic; and being dry,
the toile, cambric, and muslin; being cut into
leaves, one needs to put a clear carmine on it; that
you see to be a very beautiful color to your liking;

Note if you see that the dye is too thick
with a glass of hide glue; one needs to take
more still, all until such time that the soup is good
Note when you would like to make less a dont [which?] one needs to

But if you see to the contrary, that you do not have

next pour the glue, in the saucer; and one needs to mix

and do as here before; but the glue, and the cambric, must be hot

The blue for flowers, which one calls
areniez, is made with English ash,
in the same manner as the starch blue,
but the blue of English ash does not
have to be rubbed into the toile as strongly as the
starch blue, because the color is finer
and it suffices, that the cambric has the color of

For making red ones one needs to take
some vermillion, and hide glue,;
the toiles being cut, in leaves, one needs to put a

The green toiles are made with hide glue,

Way to wash the velum. One needs to
put to soak in the evening, and the next day, one
washes it, as one washes the laundry, piece by piece,
in rain water or fountain water, entirely
cold, without ever heating it. Nor
for the soaking, because the velum or parchment,
will become as easy to tear
as paper in heating the water. One washes it
in this way, twice a day, changing
the water each time, and this thusly eight days in
a row. But when the parchment is written [upon] with
red letters, one needs to scrape the said letter. After ~
having washed the parchment, two or three days, one
takes it out of the water, and one spreads it out on a
very smooth board, all wet like it is, one scrapes the
red letters with the sharp edge of a pen-knife or a knife,
grating [it]. One needs to hold one's hand very lightly, and
turn the parchment on both sides. If there are ~
red letters there too, one needs to scrape so well that one
cannot see anything of the red, because the green doesn't have enough strength
to cover the red, nor musical notes,
as it is not appropriate for making green. . ~~~

After the parchment, is scraped one
throws them into water immediately, next being well
washed, and eight days have passed, if the water remains
clear it is a sign that it is washed enough. ~~

Way to gild with gold or silver
The only thing that one wants to burnish is gold
or silver. One must first prepare the ground
with strong glue. Being dry, lay next
a layer of lime with white ceruse, paying attention
continually that you do not ever lay a second layer
unless the first is entirely dry. And do not
leave it ever to dry where it is very
sunny. And do not lay the white too thickly. One
must lay it 9 or 10 times. Then refine [it]
and make it very even with a
wolfs tooth or with water from Spanish
soap, and scour it with it until it
is even. Next, one must leave it to rest
at least one day. Before you go to gild or
silver it, only under the gild [areas] one puts
the two last coats of glue, some white
ceruse, and orange paint, on the ground
to have gold color. ~~~~
Bile of an eel melted in some brandy
is good for illuminating gold or silver
in the following colors: green, black, grey,
and yellow.
It does so that the paint flows, and makes that
it does not flake off. This small quantity of
gall from an eel is but only for drawing
with a paintbrush on little images, but as we make

larger work, so must one take larger
quantities of gall and brandy.
Note: if you only wish to make light work,
with 4 or 5 ground [layers] to lay
it is already enough. ~~~~
Note that eel gall is only
for illuminating but not for
drawing with a paintbrush on
little images. To that end, brandy
works well on its own. Also one or two little
drops of rainwater or fountain water, this is the best
to put in the shell with gold or silver and therewith to
gild with foam[?] gold or silver. The
ground must be made slightly wet with
well beaten egg white, but overall well wet.
Thereafter, one lays the gold or the silver foam thereupon,
fine or rough, one puts it down with a small
brockskens sponge, well washed beforehand, [and]
thereafter squeezed out in a cloth, and thereafter,
gilded with. And if the sponge becomes somewhat
too dry, one does as before. ~~
Note: if it is with oil, one takes ghebrant[drying?]
oil and one makes it wet with this oil, and
[lays] silver or gold foam thereupon. And one
does with the sponge as before. ~~

St. Augustine

JESUS, MARY, AUGUSTINE.
Since the Holy Spirit allows us to praise, after death, those people who deserve
to be praised; it is beyond just, to give a tribute so legitimate to the memory of the
REVEREND MOTHER
MOTHER ADRIENE TERESE DE MALDEGHEM,
Cannonesse Regular of the Order of St. Augustine, who died in Tournai in the Monastery of Our Lady of Sion
on the 28th of the year 1680, among the prayers and sorrows of her dear Sisters, after having received the Holy Sacraments of the Church
with as much piety, as resignation to the Divine will. 65 years of age, & Professed of her vows for 48, a life that had been as
Religious as hers for so many years, could not have promised an ending less Happy: grace
perfecting the advantages pulled from her Illustrious Lineage, rendered her a living example of all the virtues,
& a subject wholly suited for the governance of others; which was brightly visible throughout her Life, & and in the
functions that she exercised as Mistress of the Novices; as Sub-prioress & Prioress with this wise, prudent, steadfast,
& Holy Conduct that was inseparable from her character: BUT, following what St Paul said; even though his conscience reproached
him with nothing, he was not yet Justified, what Holiness could deliver a person from this healthy fear of the
Judgments of God! Thus although we have so many Indications of her eternal happiness, we implore Sacrifices
& prayers; Such that if divine Justice should demand of her any remaining expiation in Purgatory, she might as soon as possible
be in a state to enjoy the chaste embraces of her heavenly Spouse, These are the charitable services that
we demand of the Religious Communities, & of all the faithful.
May she rest in peace.

St Godelieve

Mr Joris, druggist, sells brazilwood
wood that is very good for painting
paper red. One does this as follows:
for two stuiverss or fives worth of
this wood according to the puddle that one wants
to make. And for the nicest, take but
a half of it. And put it in a pot with
a can or three pints of rainwater.
Let it extract somewhat and then cook[boil?] it for half an hour
or somewhat more. Then a piece of red alum,
finely pounded, but one must first, in a dish or pan,
smilten[melt?] [it] on its own. But one must understand that this does not
appear red but is white, but it is so named. And with
the outside also cooked, while the wood has simmered
for so long, then you pour the soup of alum in the
first pot and stir it around with a stocktien. Then the
whole thing becomes red. And let it simmer together somewhat, then pour some
soup in a little pot. And once it is cool, take white paper and lay it on

a table [and] begin to paint. But one must lay a bad [cloth]
or something that cannot be injured underneath, and hang every
sheet from a little cord all over. But then let a
pack of little cords dry and continue thus
until that is red enough, according to your taste, all over
up to six or seven times. [If] you want to have it
shiny, go over it with egg white, finely
beaten. This soup is also good to make silk red,
especially a white ground or yellow. But [it] must first be
washed clean af linten[?bits of the brazilwood?]. But one must cook
herein a little bit. It is also good for making withe wood red.
And once it is red enough, paint it with [egg] wash. It shines
and is like mahogany. The ground of this can serve more
than once. With other water and a bit more wood
therein and alum, [it] is a good sap again.
But the size of the alum [needed for] such a double
bucket one surely learns oneself.

To subtract red [from] cloth
One must make lye. Take cold
vines and burn it to ashes. Take two pots
of rain water and put the ashes and pour the
clear lye off into a new earthenware pot
and take the red cloth and put it in the lye
until it is saturated [lit. overjuiced], and put the pot, well covered
with an earthenware lid in the evening from the fire
in the lukewarm oven and let it process until
the next day at the fire. Then take
the same pot and place it on a cupboard
with fire (?? chafing dish?) and let it cook for an hour. And let it
turn about constantly with a new pot
spoon [so] that it doesn't burn. Then take
after a new earthenware pot and take the first
from the fire and begin to squeeze the cloth out
into the second pot, and once the wetness is out, take
a half pint of white wine vinegar and stir this in
slowly throughout and let it cook on a still
fire and stir it so that it does not burn until a ____.
And then let it sit until it has sunk, and
pour the the uppermost [liquid] off and take the cloth and throw
it on the floor and let [it] dry thus.
And the brightest is for dyeing paper

Way to dye paper red
Put an ounce of potash in
an earthenware pot, then boil
a stoop of rainwater and
pour it, all boiling, on the
potash, let it stand
untouched until the next day. Then
gently, without stirring, pour the clear
lye out into another
clean pot. Then take a kanne
of this lye, set it to boil
and take a pound of red cloth
put this in a clean pot and once
the lye has boiled, pour it on the
cloth, let it somewhat trecken
on the fire, turning the cloth
from time to time. Once it is all well
drunken through, take remove it [from the fire]
and let it stand to cool some
then put the other kanne of lye
on the fire. Let it boil. Then squeeze out
the cloth as tightly as you
can, and while the lye boils, put
the cloth in it. Turn
and stir it well. Let [it] boil for a quarter
of an hour. Then let it cool
a bit. Squeeze it out again.
Then, add all the soup and
place this on the fire. Put
a susijn of white alum in it.
Let this boil a bit. The foam
must not be thrown
away since good dye can
come from it. Then put a bit of
white tartar in a pot
and pour the boiling dye on top of it.
If you see that there is still foam
forming, take it off, and and
do not put it with the other foam. Then
let it sit for two or three days
without stirring. Then gently pour
all the dye off, and see if the
sediment is dirty or if there are black
bits in it. If there are any in it, then
it isnt good. If the sediment is clean,
put it in with the dye. Then place
it again on the fire. If it is
purple, it is that there is not enough
tartar in it. Also, if there is
too much tartar in it, it is
too pale. Then put some starch
dust-bloom?? in a pot, crush

it with the cold soup that
came from the scum, and once the
dye boils, then put it in the pot
where the bloom is, boiling it all
so that the bloom does not clump.
Once the dye becomes purple, then
put some more tartar with the bloom
until you see that it is a beautiful
color. Note that the dye
cannot be bottled and cannot
be kept for long, but
can be reboiled if it has
become purple. Let it boil
a bit. Then put some tartar in
another pot, pour the dye over
it, take the foam off, and if
it is still too purple, put some
more tartar with it until that you see
that it is beautiful. And once no more
foam appears, one must
let it stand until it settles.
Then pour it gently out.
See if the sediment is good,
as [you did] before, and put it in a pot.
Let it come to a boil.
Take some bloom, as was said
before. The dryer the place
where the dye is kept, the
better it will keep.
One can also paint with this.
And if one wants to have
light yellow, one must put some
rainwater with it.

To dye a red color one needs to take a large handful
of fine linen and then one takes a half pound of safflower, where those
safflowers need to be bundled in a little linen bag and then one puts
the safflower that are in the little bag in rainwater for six or seven hours
to soak, and now and then turn the little bag in the water.
And when it has soaked long enough one needs to wash the little bag,
without it coming open, as long as the little bag is still red [OR: long enough until the little bag becomes red]
Now, to make the lye, you must take grapevine wood
and burn it to ashes, of which ashes one needs to take
a pot full and one puts them in a kettle with two pots
of rainwater. And leave it thus only a half hour to cook, and then take
the kettle off the fire and let it settle, as the lye must
be clear. And then begin to dye, end then place the little bag
with the safflower in a dish and shake over it a clean
little beer glass half full of lye, shake it over the little bag and
wash the little bag with it and then wring the little bag
half out, and then add in the whitest linen and once it is wet
then squeeze it out, then take a little dish of vinegar and put that little piece
of linen in the vinegar, about a little glassfull, then squeeze it out, take again the
same little piece of linen that had been in the dye, put it again
in the same dye, squeeze it out thus, and put it again in the
same vinegar, then squeeze it out. Then, throw the vinegar out and put
clean vinegar in the little dish, and then throw the dye out also
Wring the aforesaid little bag out, then take the previous
piece that is still dyed and put it again therein, so then squeeze it
out again and place it again in the vinegar, then squeeze it out again. Then
the piece is red enough. Then, you must take once more another white piece
of linen, and place it in the dye and then again in the vinegar just as
before; and once the dye becomes clear, then throw it out and then lay the
little bag in the dish, then pour another half little glass of lye over the
little bag, and then wring it therewith, wring the little bag half
out, and then begin to dye again in the same manner as before.
And as you notice that there is no more dye coming out and [it runs] clear,
then you must stop dyeing, then you must wash the red linen,
with some Spanish [i.e., castille] soap, but you must put the soap in a clean
little cloth and then beat the little cloth with the soap there in the water. Thus
must you then wash [it], piece by piece, in a bucket, and then rinse with clean
water. Then wring it out and lay it in a dish and then put
vinegar over it. Let it stand thus therein for a whole night. Then the next day,
wring it out, and then lay it to dry on a serge, and that
in the dark, and then once it is dry, you must stiffen it with white starch.
You must take a quarter of a pound and then let it become cold.
Then must you thus stiffen linen, and out of one another, put [it] also on a
serge, and that in the dark. Let it dry thus.
Now, to make white roses, so must you take white linen and put
it in the soap water that the red linen was washed in,
and with clear water rinsed, but put it in no vinegar, though
stiffen it as before.

To dye paper yellow
One takes a sisein [=coinage type] of saffron, which one lets extract in the quantity
of a pint of water. Once it is reasonably well extracted, one pours it off
and puts some more water over the saffron to further extract it. One
must also have an ounce of gum, which must be soaked for a few days
ahead of time and poured into the extracted saffron once it is cold.
[THU: note the once it is cold at the end, which is the only clue that the extraction of the saffron takes place with heat]

To make green paper
Take the greens of celery, the youngest of all the ribs,
removed and pounded in a mortar, then
wrung out, and then pounded again, three times.
Then take verdigris and boil it in the soup
until it is melted. Put in as much as
you want to have green. The more green, the
higher [=more intense] the color. Also, a bit of tartar. From time
to time, stir until the whole thing is melted. Then take
the paper and lay it on a table or board. Then take
a little painters knife and stroke it thereover.
Then the one side being done, leave it to dry,
and being well dry, then do the other side, and
that so many times until it is green enough.
After that, according to taste, take then egg white,
stroke it thereover to give a glare once
it is very dry.

Way to make ashes from grapevine tendrils
One can these, by a pure heart, without mixing
other ashes in, that are newly burnt, one puts it on the fire and the ashes
all together in a bad/old earthenware pot, which one from time
to time pokes, until it is all consumed.
To make lye from grapevine-tendril ash
Take three handfuls of ashes [scooped] with two hands, and 7 or 8
pints of rain or fountain water, let this cook until [it reduces to] 4 or 5
pints, should be cooked in a clean [metal] marmite. Once it is
removed from the fire, it must be cast [i.e., levigated] into a metal pot that
has not been used for any other thing, such as dyeing red,
leaving the ashes, so much as possible, on the bottom of the
marmite. The next day, one pours the ashes through a cloth
into another pot, still careful not to move [what is on]
the bottom. The lye is then good to use to dye a pink color,
as follows here.
Take a quarter or half pound of safflower, put it in a little
white linen bag, securely tied, place it to soak
in rain or fountain water. One washes(?) the safflower a little
itself, changing the water two times, and then letting [it] soak
from five-thirty in the evening until five-thirty in the morning.
And then is it washed, and from time to time, its
water is changed until it is clear. The bag should not
be wrung out but removed from the water with the hands, except for
the last time: then, the little bag must be very firmly wrung out,
as much as is possible.

After, one pulls the safflower out of the bag and puts it
in a large, flat[-bottomed] pot, and once everything is thoroughly picked
[out of the bag], one sprinkles there a little rain or fountain water
over [it]. Then one pours into the safflower a pint of lye made
from the ashes of grapevine tendrils. Then is the pot covered
with another of the same size, so that it
can catch the air. Set it in a dark place,
set a covering-cloth over it, and let it proceed
for 2 hours, and [it] must then be bruised for 15 minutes.
One must remove it by handfuls. Once one can
take no more [out], pour the rest into the bag again, [and] this
is wrung out into a clean pot. One prepares immediately
another pot with some white wine vinegar, in which the fabric
is made wet. Being well drunk, one takes these [i.e., the vinegar-soaked fabric and the lyed petals]
all together, gives them into the hands of the person that
bruised and and wrung out the safflower, which entire mass alike had
been set in the dye. Wash these same [things] well one by one.
Proceed with a light hand as quickly as is possible.
The fabric, having her color, is washed again, piece by
piece, after having removed [un-dunked] it well. Put them in verjuice
after [they] are squeezed out as before. [They] are rinsed in three or 4
pots following before prepared with 2 or 3 pints of clean
rain or fountain water, where after one washes a few pieces of fabric
therein [once] the first color is rinsed in, which serves
as a pale color and is then dried together in the attic. [is there a little flower at the end?]
